titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. V:30. Walk round Capitol Square. Fahrenheit 13.

This succession of visitors absorbed the whole day and Evening; and left me no time for writing. Mr Graham brought me to sign two Proclamations for Sales of Lands. And a Sale of a Reserve, by a Choctaw Indian half breed, named Louis Godfrey to approve. Watkins brought me to read a Letter to him from John Binns at Philadelphia; about the appointment of a Collector at that place— He has heard of the project of obtaining the appointment of J. A. Schulze—which he warmly dissuades. His voice is for Jonathan Roberts— Watkins spoke of the bitter aversion certain Members of Congress from Virginia, against the Administration—particularly of Mercer and Bassett against Webster— Mercer is smarting under defeat in an attempt to take the lead out of Webster’s hands, upon the Bill for enlarging the U.S. Judiciary. Watkins mentioned also a question still pending on the Settlement of Captain David Porter’s Accounts— Messrs.Knight and Isacks brought me four enrolled Bills which I signed and sent back to the respective Houses— I sent also to the Senate an answer to their last call for papers; but they had adjourned before my Son reached the Capitol, on account of the death of Henry Chambers, a Senator elect from Alabama who died in Virginia, on his way hither to take his Seat— Mr Barrell came with a claim for the widow of the late General Hull— He shewed me a Letter written by the late President Monroe—dated the 2d. of March last; and admitting the validity of Hull’s claim, which he had always before rejected. I told Mr Barrell he must go for Settlement to the War Department. Mr Strong, member of the House from New York introduced Thérouanne a young Frenchman. And Coll. Jones came with Dr Monroe a Surgeon in the army, and with Mr Noland recently from Arkansas; the person whom I met last Summer at Mr Monroe’s house in Loudoun County, and who accompanied us to Leesburg— Mr Thomas Findlay was a visitor from Baltimore— Captain Douglas of West Point, left with me a Letter from him to the Superintendent Coll. Thayer, proposing himself to go on a Mission of a year to Europe; to study fortifications and engineering. He urgently recommended himself for this mission— Mr D. Brent came with the Papers called for by a Resolution of the Senate two days since; and I sent them with a Message to the Senate— Mr Morton from Bordeaux called to visit; and Mr Sanford newly arrived, a Senator from New-York— Took his Seat in the Senate yesterday. Mr Rush was here, and brought papers relating to the appointment of a Collector at Pensacola— He has determined to appoint Ebenezer French to the Clerkship vacated by the Resignation of Captain Richards— Mr Mills the Senator was here in the Evening— The Panama Mission was again postponed in Senate, on account of the ill health of Mr Tazewell, and some other Senators— The Resolution in the House of Representatives calling for the papers was again debated this day. The opposition are coalescing against it— There is also much debate upon the bill making appropriations for Fortifications. The Committee of the House of Representatives upon the public buildings, Van Rensselaer, James Findlay of Ohio, and Miner of Pennsylvania this morning visited the house; but I did not see them— Mr Mills took an Oyster Supper with us— A hazardous experiment to me; and that it might be innoxious, I sat writing in my chamber an hour and a half afterward, and till near midnight.
2. V:30. Capitol Square Fahrenheit 26.

General Van Rensselaer came to introduce Mr Tibbits of New-York. W. R. King Senator and G. M. Owen Member of the House of Representatives from Alabama, came to recommend a Mr Dillet as District Judge U.S. in that State— Tait’s resignation was received yesterday— King and Owen are exceedingly averse to the appointment of Crawford; in whose favour the recommendations are numerous and highly respectable— Mr Kerr, a member of the House of Representatives from Maryland, brought me a letter urging the appointment of a youth named Harrison, to be a Cadet at West-Point. Kerr said he himself had recommended another person in his district. Gouverneur is lately from New-York going to see Mr Monroe at Loud oun— Charles Hay had a paper from the Secretary of the Navy— W. Hunter came for some papers not to be found at the War Department, and which I have not. Mrs Sherburne, wife of the Man dismissed from a Clerkship at the Navy Department, came to solicit and to plead her poverty and her five children— Mr Clay came and prepared a Letter of Instruction to send to Mr Anderson at Bogota, ordering him to come and meet Mr Sergeant at Porto-Bello; thence to proceed to Panama— He spoke also of appointing the Legislative Council of the Michigan Territory; and I expressed to him my doubts, on the territorial Law, by virtue of which the election was held in districts— He asked me to see Governor Cass, and promised to give him notice to call upon me to-morrow Morning. He also thought it would be indispensably necessary to appoint W. Crawford as District Judge in Alabama— Said there was no doubt he was the person best qualified— Mrs Adams and Miss Mease were both unwell— Confined to their chambers all day.
3. VI. To the Capitol— Thaw— Snow disappearing.

Dr Thornton observed that I had some months since asked him for a view of the Patent-Office System; and of any improvements of which it might be susceptible. He had accordingly sent me a paper on the subject, and now came to enquire if I wished any thing further concerning it. I told him it was under the Consideration of a Committee of the House of Representatives— If they should propose any new Legislation concerning Patents, they would require information, which he could give them— But I thought it not probable they would revise the Patent Laws, at least during the present Session of Congress. Mr Lowry brought me a copy of the proceedings of the Senate upon the nomination of Daniel Bissell as Colonel of the Second Regiment of Artillery. Instead of acting upon the nomination they have passed a Resolution that in the opinion of the Senate Bissell is a Coll and Brevet Brigadier General in the army, and that the President may arrange him accordingly. Judge Cranch told me that the Columbia College had determined to annex a Law School to their Institution, and had elected him a Professor, to which he had reluctantly assented— He had recommended a young Mr Carroll, who is elected an adjunct professor with him. A Mr Bartlett of Utica New York, brought a book elegantly bound as a present to Mrs Adams. Joseph M White Delegate from Florida, came to urge the appointment of a Collector at Pensacola, in the place of Hamilton— White anxiously recommends Robert Mitchell— Governor Cass of Michigan reasoned with me upon the validity of the territorial act, prescribing an election
of the persons from whom the 13 members of the Legislative Council, are to be selected, by Districts— I had doubts whether this territorial Law was conformable to the acts of Congress, but the territorial Legislature were authorised to prescribe the manner of the election and under that word manner, directed that it should be by Districts— And now if the selection is made from those having the greatest number of all the votes, all the members will be from two or three of the districts, and the others will be quite unrepresented— This and some other Considerations induced me to acquiesce in the Act of the Legislature of the Territory— Mr Rush and Mr Anderson the Secretary and Comptroller of the Treasury spoke of the condition of Mr G. Hay’s accounts while he was District Attorney— He offers a pledge of his Estate, to satisfy any balance that may be found against him on future Settlement; instead of present Settlement, and persists in claims for allowances which cannot be made. I thought there would be danger in sending such a State of facts; and such a mortgage to the Committee of the Senate, and advised that he should withdraw the deed and if possible make the Settlement.— I gave the Comptroller also Mr James L. Cathcart’s Memorial and Documents; to act upon them as he should think proper. Mr Jesse B. Thomas, Senator from Illinois came to speak about the Prospects in the Senate of the Nomination to the Panama Mission— He avows himself to be friendly to the Administration— W. H. Allen from Florida, Edward Ingersoll, G. Sullivan, and David Hoffman of Baltimore called on morning visits, and a Mr Leland, now from Georgetown came to ask for a place; and told me that he came from Massachusetts a year or two since, and settled himself here for the express purpose of obtaining a place. We had Company to dine. W. H. Allen, John Anderson, Thomas H. Benton, Titus Brown, John Findlay, Thomas Findlay, Revd. Mr Hawley, Moses Hayden, Michael Hoffman, David Hoffman, Edward Ingersoll, Samuel Lathrop, Philip Markley, Elisha Phelps, Alfred H. and Mrs Powell, Asher Robbins, Samuel Smith, George Sullivan, Samuel Swan, Bartow White, Calvin Willey and T. J. Worthington; with the family and Miss Mease 30. Genl. Bogardus of New-York, W. L. and Mrs Brent, Don Manuel de Escudero the Mexican John Forsyth, Gabriel Holmes, Jonathan Jennings (by mistake for his brother David) the Revd. Mr M’Ilvaine, John M’Kee, Thomas Metcalfe, J. K. Polk, and Cuthbert Powell were invited but came not— Our dining hour is five: but it was past seven when we sat down to table— The House of Representatives sat till half past six, debating a Resolution to call upon the President for the Correspondence, relating to the Panama Mission, and the Objects in which it is expected our Ministers are to take part— They finally passed the Resolution by a vote of 124 to 40 as modified by Mr Webster; but there has been much manoeuvring in the house, first to defeat the Resolution, indirectly, and secondly to clog it with embarrassments to the Executive— There was a Union, of Crawford, Calhoun and Jackson partizans, to baffle the friends of the Administration— Cambreleng proposed to call for the Instructions to the Ministers; M’Duffie wanted their Powers, Ingham moved to strike out the usual exception of such information as it might be incompatible with the public interest to communicate; and the testing vote was upon that motion which was lost 78. to 98.— Forsyth talked of the power of the House to send their Serjeant at Arms to bring the President of the United States before them— Forsyth was to have dined with me, but sent a note of excuse, that he was too much exhausted— Dr Huntt says Forsyth’s temper was raised by a blister on the back of his neck, which was drawing when he spoke.
4. V:30. To the Capitol. Sun rose 6:56. directly behind South turret of the Capitol.

William Findlay, Senator from Pennsylvania came to introduce his Son John. Lowry the Secretary of the Senate, brought me the advice and consent of the Senate to the Ratification of thirteen Indian Treaties. Clarke brought me the Resolution of the House adopted yesterday, and relating to the Panama Mission— M’Lane, North and Ogden are three old Revolutionary Officers who called merely to pay a morning visit—as did D. Webster with David B. Ogden, who is here to attend upon the Supreme Court. U.S— Their Session commences next Monday. Mr Ward, Member of H.R.U.S. introduced Mr Kemble of New-York— Mr Smith is the U.S. judge in East-Florida; here to defend himself against the charges of Edgar Macon, the District Attorney in his own Court. White, the Florida Delegate came again about the appointment of Collector at Pensacola— Hodgson came to take leave— Going tomorrow for Algiers, to learn the Turkish and Arabic Languages and if possible the Persian— I allow him three years after which he is to return to this Country— Governor Barbour brought me his Letter to the Chairman of the Committee of Indian Affairs in the House of Representatives, containing his plan for the future disposal of the Indians— Mr Clay brought me his draft of Instructions to the Ministers to be sent to the Congress at Panama; and he was anxious to send off immediately a Messenger to Mr Anderson at Bogota, directing him to come down to the Coast there to meet J. Sergeant. I asked him how if the Senate should reject the nominations? Why then Mr Anderson must go back to Bogota; and the expense of his journies would be the only inconvenience suffered. But Mr Clay will not believe it possible that the Senate should reject the nominations— I was engaged all the Evening—writing.
5. V:45. To the Central Market— Cloudy.

Heard this Morning Mr Little from Acts 28.30.31. [“]Paul dwelt two whole years in his own hired house, and received all that came unto him— Preaching the kingdom of God, and teaching those things which concern the Lord Jesus Christ with all confidence no man forbidding him.” And in the afternoon Mr Baker, from Solomon’s Song 5.16. “This is my friend”— The text is only a small part of the verse, and thus extracted from the context presents a different meaning from that which it bears in the whole verse— The friend, in Mr Baker’s exposition is Christ, and that opens at once upon the beaten path— Between the Services, Mr J. B. Cutting called and mentioned to my Son John that one of the New-York Newspapers spoke of an arrival from Havre announcing the Death of the Emperor Alexander at Taganrok on the Sea of Azoff. He died it is said of his old lame leg, the Erisypelis striking to it; about the 1st of December. The account of this event travelled first to Warsaw—thence to Berlin, whence it was sent by a Telegraphic despatch, from the French Minister to his Government; and reached Paris the 17th. of Decr. The Emperor Alexander, was perhaps of all living men the man whose life was most important to the rest of mankind— To what changes his death may lead conjecture is at fault. From personal motives, I ought to cherish his memory, for through my Agency, he rendered essential good Offices to my Country. His influence upon the history of my life has been great and auspicious— Daniel P. Cook spent part of the Evening with me.
6. V:45— Central Market— Sun rose 6:54. behind the dome of the Capitol.

Mr Southard came with a Letter from Major Wainwright of the Marine Corps, applying for promotion by brevet— Mr Seymour a Senator from Vermont spoke of the case of James Fiske; Collector at Allburgh; and the charges against him to prevent his renomination. Fiske is here to repel these charges; Seymour thinks effectively; but on his arrival finds new and other charges, for which he was not prepared; and wants time to go home and collect the means of refuting them— I was engaged when Mr Johnson called, and did not see him— Clarke and Trimble came to remonstrate against the appointment of John Adair as Chargé d’Affaires to Peru, upon which they manifested great anxiety— They spoke of his age, of his incompetency, and of his bitter inveteracy against the Administration. Also of his deep engagedness in the political divisions of the State of Kentucky on the side of the judge-breaking party— I said I had entertained a friendly disposition towards Genl. Adair, since the time when I had sat with him in the Senate; but that I could not with propriety select another diplomatic agent to an American State, from Kentucky. D. Chase the Senator from Vermont came and introduced his brother who is the Bishop of Ohio. The Judges of the Supreme Court came on a visit of ceremony with the Marshal. Judges Johnson and Story have not yet arrived, and Judge Todd is confined at home, never expected to recover— The Court met this day. James Phillips came for a subscription for a Baptist School of Teachers in Ohio— Mr Clay informed me that Mr. Warfield who has been here definitively declines going to Bogota— Yet Mr Clay had prepared a Letter to Mr Anderson, directing him to come to Carthagena, and was for despatching it, without waiting for the decision of the Senate upon the nominations. I thought it better to postpone this measure; being more and more doubtful, whether they will confirm the nomination at-all— Mr Clay mentioned also the proceedings of the Senate on the case of D. Bissell, in which they have substituted their opinion in the place of the Law— I said I thought the subject was in a state which could only be remedied by an Act of Congress— Govr. Barbour called and I returned him his Letter to the Chairman of the Indian Committee, which he had left with me and which I had read— He appeared desirous that it should be submitted to a meeting of the members of the Administration, and I desired him to give them notice to meet here to-morrow at Noon— This Evening was absorbed by successive visits from Mr Edward Everett and Mr Mills— The latter of whom told me that the Senate had this day, at the motion of H. L. White of Tennessee, laid on the Table the Message nominating Ministers to Panama, avowedly with the purpose of not taking it up, till I shall have answered the call from the House of Representatives, and if that should be public, then the Senate would open their doors and discuss the subject in public also—
7. V:15. Capitol— Rain and fog.

Dr Watkins spoke of the transformation recently undergone by the Newspaper called the Washington City Gazette— It has been sold by its Publisher Jonathan Elliot, and Watkins says purchased by John H. Eaton, Senator from Tennessee— Its name is changed to that of United States Telegraph and its first number was published last week— The Prospectus avows a determined opposition to the present Administration; and from a sample of bad English peculiar to Calhoun, I have no doubt is from his hand. Watkins asked me if I thought any notice should be taken of this Declaration of War— I said no. John Findlay came with Mr Weaver one of the superintendents of the Continuation of the Cumberland Road. He gave me some particulars of their progress in the Work— Mr Archer came and introduced Dr Crump, the member elected in the place of John Randolph, and against the competition of W. B. Giles. Messrs.Wilson, Miles and Gaither came to complain that having purchased lots in the City of Captain John Davidson, and built upon them, he had given them no title, he having bought them at a public Sale of the city lots; but never paid any part of the purchase money— They were willing to pay the sums at which their lots had been struck off to him, for a title deed— And as Mr Elgar declined giving it to them; they applied to me to give him better advice— I told them, I feared he had no power to do otherwise; but desired them to ask Mr Elgar to call on me to-morrow Morning— Messrs.Rush, Barbour, Southard and Wirt were here in Cabinet Meeting upon Mr Barbour’s Letter to the Chairman of the Committee on Indian Affairs of the House of Representatives— The Letter was read and variously commented upon by the other Members of the Administration— Mr Clay was absent, confined to his house by a relapse of the Influenza— Mr Barbour’s plan is differently modified, from that which he had at first prepared— He has given up the idea of incorporating the Indians into the Several States where they reside— He has now substituted that of forming them all into a great territorial Government West of the Mississippi— There are many very excellent observations in the paper; which is full of benevolence and humanity— I fear there is no practicable plan by which they can be organized into one civilised or half-civilised Government— Mr Rush, Mr Southard and Mr Wirt, all expressed their doubts of the practicability of Governor Barbour’s plan; but they had nothing more effective to propose; and I approved it from the same motive— Mr Wirt told me he had heard in Court this day that there was great excitement in the Senate at the Resolution adopted last Friday in the House of Representatives calling for the Papers and objects of the Panama Mission—considering it as a stimulant upon them concerted between the Executive and the majority of the House— Mr Wirt said he was told this by persons friendly to the Administration but declined naming them. He suggested that it might be well to send a Message to the House, to appease this excitement of the Senate— The annual Meeting of the Commissioners of the sinking fund was held this morning, and Calhoun there manifested his purpose of draining the Treasury, by applying the balance of the last year’s appropriation to paying off debt; beyond the ten Millions a year appropriated by Law— He obtained no countenance to his Scheme either from the Chief Justice or the Attorney-General— The Secretary of State was absent— Mr Bouligny the Senator from Louisiana, brought me a Letter from Bishop Dubourg, recommending a person named Antoine Dupuy for the appointment of Postmaster at New-Orleans— And Mr Bouligny also himself very earnestly recommended him.
8. V:30. Central Market— Sun rose 6.51. behind Turret, and perched on dome. symbols

Elgar came upon the subject of Captain Davidson’s deeds: but I found that I had no power to authorise deeds to be made to his grantees: and I concurred with Elgar that I could not comply with the wishes of Mr Baker’s Church for the Square they desired to have for a burying yard: it being too near the centre of the City. I desired him to give notice of this to Mr Baker and Dr Lovell— Mr Cook came and introduced to me a Mr Breeze from Illinois. Genl. Smith came with Letters concerning an interdiction of our vessels from entering the Port of Halifax, or any other of the British Colonies. This is a new Provincial movement?, founded upon a doubtful Construction by the Collector at Halifax, of a late Act of Parliament— Smith’s Correspondents and he himself wish me instantly to issue a Proclamation admitting British vessels from the Colonies on the same terms as our own, to avert the Interdiction; but I am not satisfied of my authority— Smith had also a claim of the State of Maryland, for interest upon certain Loans during the late War— And he wished me to send a Message recommending it to the Senate as Mr Monroe had done for the State of Virginia— I promised to examine the papers, which Smith said he would send to me; and if I found the precedent would justify me, I would readily send the Message— Smith spoke also of the proceedings of the Senate on the Panama Nomination, and said he had voted for the laying them on the table for delay— I said I had a thought of sending a Message to the House saying that I could not answer their Resolution till the Senate should have acted upon the nomination— Smith said that would put them upon velvet— Mr Brent was here twice, having in the interval seen Mr Clay at his house where he is confined by indisposition— He was much averse to the sending of the Message which I proposed to the House; thinking it would be taken as a reproof by our friends in the House who adopted the Resolution. Judge William Johnson of the Supreme Court paid me a morning visit. just arrived from Charleston, S.C. Governor Cass of the Michigan Territory with Dr Hendricks, Senator from Indiana, Mr Wing the Delegate from Michigan, Mr Connor and Tipton a Senator in the Indiana Legislature, and an Interpreter, came with Le Gros a Miami Indian Head-Man who has been here sometime, and was unwilling to go away without seeing his great father the President— He made me a speech to that effect which was interpreted to me and which I answered and told him I thought I had seen him before— He had been here in 1805. Cass said it would be a great point of honour for him upon his return to his tribe, to have it to say that he had seen the President— Mr George Hay was here— Still in trouble about his accounts— Declined dining with me on Friday not wishing to shew himself in Company while this Cloud hangs over him— He spoke of Internal Improvements to the making of which he said he had no sort of objection, though he did not think Congress possessed the Constitutional power to make them. But he considered the question as settled; and it was useless to be forever reviving it— General Brown was here, and enquiring what had been done concerning the appointment of Coll. or General Bissell— I had done nothing— Mr Scott of Missouri had also called to know— I have answered that I have by Law no power to act until the Senate shall have acted upon my nomination of him— General Brown adverted to the course of the New-York Delegation in the House of Representatives. 28 of the 34 members in the recent debate, on the Call, voted on the side of the Administration; all as Brown says, friends of Governor Clinton—upon which he descanted much. This Evening was the fifth Drawing Room, and the most crowded with company of any one this Season— Mrs Adams however could not attend it, being confined by illness to her bed—
9. VI. To Central Market.

Mr Cook came at the desire of Mr Jesse B. Thomas, Senator from the State of Illinois; to say that his disposition was friendly to the Administration, and that he would be glad to take an opportunity of calling to converse with me— I requested Cook to say to Mr Thomas that I should be happy to see and converse with him, whenever it would be agreeable to himself— General Cocke of Tennessee came with Major Walker, on account of a claim by a Major Houston, for certain Whiskey which he was some years since carrying for sale to Mobile— He left it in the Custody of a principle Chief of the Cherokees; but the Creeks came and stole it away— This claim was brought before the late Secretary of War, Calhoun, who rejected it— They have brought it before Governor Barbour, for revision; but he declines reversing a decision of his Predecessor— Mr Cocke after laying down his positions, said he must insist that I would revise the case; to which I made no answer. he left the papers with me— Mr Cathcart came for a decision upon his Memorial concerning the payment of the award of the Florida Treaty Claim Commissioners in his favour— The question is how far the Officers of the Treasury Department, are bound to obey the injunctions of judicial Courts— In the opinion of the Attorney General is that their deference to them is Discretionary. I referred Mr Cathcart to the Secretary and Comptroller of the Treasury— Governor Cass came to take leave— I told him I should nominate to the Senate for the Legislative Council of Michigan, the list of persons as recommended by him. I mentioned that a person whose name I did not know, had asked me last Evening at the Drawing room, whether I had decided; saying he wished to know because he was going for Detroit this Morning. I told him I had not decided. Cass said it was a strange question, but the person who had put it, had good intentions— It was Sheldon, Printer of a Newspaper at Detroit. George Sullivan came and requested me to consider favorably the case of Edgar Macon, District Attorney in East Florida— I said I had understood Macon was here, not to defend himself but to prefer charges for the impeachment of Joseph L. Smith the Judge of U.S. in East Florida. Sullivan said that was partly true, but that Smith had silenced him as a lawyer in his Court, and wished to have him removed as District Attorney— Sullivan said the man was a very young and a very honourable man— That he had perhaps indiscreetly undertaken this impeachment of Judge Smith— That the charges had been referred to the Committee on the Judiciary in the House of Representatives; who were of opinion that they were sustained, but declined reporting an impeachment, because Smith was a Territorial Judge, and the remedy would be within the power of the President— That young Macon was here, friendless; for that although a Nephew of the Senator of that name, he had refused to give him any support and countenance; and that he Sullivan, seeing this young man in his present difficulties felt a great interest in his favour; and now ventured this application to me in his behalf— He made it entirely without Macon’s knowledge, and only desired that I would not condemn him without giving him an opportunity to justify himself— I said that should certainly be afforded him if a complaint against him should be made— I had as yet heard of none— Mr. Southard spoke of Commodore Rodgers’sSon, who is one of the Cadets at West-Point reported to be dismissed for incompetency— And on account of his father’s absence was very anxious that he should be allowed the chance of one more semi-annual examination— Southard brought also a claim of Major Wainwright of the Marine Corps, for brevet promotion, and mentioned his wish to send upon
some employment abroad, for a time, M’Kean Buchanan, a Clerk in the Navy Department, who has involved himself in trouble here— Messrs.Pearce, Miller of N. York, Bailey, and Taylor the Speaker of the House were successively here in the Evening.
10. V. Capitol Square. Rain.

Mr Graham came and introduced Mr Love of Virginia who is an applicant for an appointment. Crowninshield called upon a morning visit. Mr Marks a Senator and Mr Stephenson a Member of the House of Representatives from Pennsylvania, came to make interest for the remission of a Sentence of a Court-Martial Cashiering a Captain Charles Pentland of the 6th. Infantry, for Drunkenness and Cruelty— He is of a very respectable family at Pittsburg— I had not read the proceedings of the Court Martial, but told these Gentlemen that I would gratify them, if I should find it possible consistently with my duty— White came to urge the appointment of Robert Mitchell as Collector at Pensacola and Letcher, besides introducing Mr Camden came to protest in very earnest terms against the appointment of John Adair as Chargé d’Affaires to Peru— He is quite as earnestly recommended by about half the members from Kentucky— Mr Brent came in the place of Mr Clay, who is confined to his house by indisposition— Mr George Hay was here; to apologize for not dining with me, as invited— He said that while under his present difficulties with regard to the Settlement of his Accounts, he felt a repugnance to going into Company any where; and by excusing himself from dining here; he could make that an apology for declining all other invitations. Mr Miner brought and introduced four Citizens of Pennsylvania, Strangers here, whose names all escaped me. Mr Southard Secretary of the Navy, brought applications from Captain Finch, and several other Officers of the Navy soliciting furloughs for six Months— Their object being to accompany Captain David Porter to Mexico— The term of Porter’s suspension by the sentence of the Court Martial finished yesterday— He has obtained a furlough for six Months longer, and proposes going there to ascertain whether it will be for his interest to enter the Mexican Service— He wishes all these Officers to go with him; and to make a numerous retinue to go into that Service with and under him. They ask leave of absence on various pretexts, but with professions of intentions not to leave our Service. I advised Mr Southard not to allow in any instance a furlough to an officer, upon the known intention upon his part to accompany Captain Porter— It is in truth an enticement of Officers from our Service; and the object is to attempt the invasion of the Island of Cuba. This is a project which we ought by no means to encourage or to countenance. If any Officer to be furloughed let it be for avowed reasons of his own concerns, but not from any connection with Porter— I called this morning at Mr Clay’s house, and found him convalescent, but much reduced. I found him still very averse to any answer’s being sent to the Resolution of the House calling for the Panama Mission papers until the Senate shall
have decided upon the nominations— My own inclination was to have sent the Message which I had prepared to the House stating that my Answer to their call must depend upon the decision of the Senate upon the nominations; but I have in accordance with the news of Mr Clay postponed this Message— Company to dine— John Baldwin, Ichabod Bartlett, John Carter, Bishop Chase, Dudley Chase, Mahlon Dickerson, Daniel Garrison, Aaron Hobart, J. C Isacks, Francis Johnson, John Leeds Kerr, William R. King, Enoch Lincoln, Edward Livingston, Mrs and Miss, Henry Markell, James S. Mitchell, Gabriel Moore, Horatio Seymour, George Sullivan, Jesse B. Thomas, Joseph M. White and Mrs— There had been invited who came not William G. Angel, Burwell Bassett, George Cary, Robert Harris, George Hay, Dutee J. Pearce, Christopher Rankin and Mrs and John Thompson. In all there were 30. at Table— Mrs Adams still remains confined to her bed.
11. V:15. Capitol Square— Cloudy.

Mr Thomas came to converse with me upon the subject of the Panama Mission; and the dispositions of some of the members of the Senate— He said there had been great exertions made to combine all the Elements of opposition against this measure, but there would ultimately be a small majority favourable to it— He spoke of J. Holmes, of Mr Kane, the other Senator from Illinois, and expressed a strong wish that Governor Bell of N. Hampshire would take a leading part; saying that he was very favourably disposed, and had much influence in the Senate— He said Kane was accessible to personal considerations, and would be anxious for the appointment of Chancellor Kent, as Postmaster at New-York, when the vacancy should happen, which was soon expected— Kent being a relation and particular friend of his father’s— Mr Garnsey came with applications for a purchase of Lands reserved to the six Nations of Indians, a Subject upon which there had already been a memorial of D. B Ogden and others— He spoke also concerning the Panama Mission, and strongly in favour of it— Mr Thomas Scott of Ohio called upon a visit— He is here to attend upon the Supreme Court— Mr Pearce called to apologize for having forgotten yesterday his engagement to dine here— Mr John Williams came to take leave; intending to go on Monday for Norfolk to embark in the John Adams, to proceed upon his Mission to Guatemala— His brother Lewis Williams came to recommend Mr Yancey of North Carolina, for the appointment of Charge d’Affaires to Peru—which I told him I would take into consideration and I assured him it would be very agreeable to me that a Citizen of North-Carolina should be appointed upon one of those Missions abroad. Mr Emmett of New York and Mr George M Bibb of Kentucky were here upon Morning visits— They are in attendance upon the Supreme Court. Mr Brent called concerning the papers to be prepared for the House of Representatives, on the Call relating to the Panama Mission. I desired him to have a copy made of all the general parts of the Instructions to R. C Anderson in 1823. Mr Southard Secretary of the Navy was here— And the Ex-Lieutenant Weaver, whom I requested not to come to me any more— I told him I had heard all that he had to say upon the case, and I should decide upon it at a proper time of which he would be duly informed. He said he would not call upon me again.
12. V:15. Capitol. Sun rose 6:46. symbols 51.

Heard at St. John’s Church, Bishop Chase, in the morning from Acts 26:26. “for this thing was not done in a corner”—an argumentative discourse in favour of Christianity, from the generality of its application to all mankind. In the afternoon he preached from Psalm 137.1. “By the rivers of Babylon, there we sat down, yea, we wept, when we remembered Zion.” His exposition of this text was somewhat mystical—considering Babylon as emblematical of the world, and Zion, of the Christian Church. But from this view of the Subject there was, it seemed to me, not so much material for the pathetic, as there would have been in a discourse drawn from the plain and direct meaning of the words, with historical reference to the time when the Psalm was written— There was a woman baptized after the reading of the Morning Prayer, and the Communion Service was read—of which I heard only the first part, on coming out from Church I met Mr Hammond of Ohio— And I called and visited Mr Clay, who is still confined to his house— Mr Sanford called to see him while I was there— Mr George Sullivan and Mr Webster, passed part of the Evening with us. Signed Blank Patents 50.
13. V. Capitol Square— Met Chief Justice Marshall— Sun rose 6:45—as October 28.

The possibility of doing business is almost in ratio inverse to the number of visitors— The Bishop solicited employment for a person named Belt; and desired also some benefaction for a College in Ohio— He went to England where he obtained some assistance for it— Though as he intimated with some opposition from his brother Hobart of New-York. Mr Mills called to mention the Embarrassment in the Senate upon the nominations for the Panama Mission— The opposition aware that there is a small majority in favour of it, are throwing every possible obstacle in the way of a decision upon it— Making question after question of a preliminary nature to waste time and endeavour to gain proselytes— Mr Powell came to introduce Mr Brown of Virginia as a Visitor— Coll. Little came to recommend a Mr Hebb as Collector at Georgetown in the place of Mr Barnes, who died three days since at the age of 96. Thomas Turner applied also for the same place, and brought many strong recommendations— He is the son of the former Accountant of the Navy Department, commissioned by my father, has a widowed Mother and Sisters to maintain, and a very good character. Mr M’Kean brought Mr Huddle of Pennsylvania to introduce him— General Smith of Baltimore came again with more Letters about the trade with the British Colonies, said to be interdicted upon a Construction given to a late Act of Parliament— Smith shewed me a Manuscript draft of a Bill, which he said he intended to present, for opening the Trade by yielding to the terms prescribed by the British— He spoke also of the Panama Mission, and asked if I should send a Message to the House of Representatives in answer to their Call— I said my present intention was to wait till the Senate should have decided upon the nominations— He asked if he might say so— I said he might— Daniel Brent was here, and I desired him to have a copy of the general part of the Instructions to R. C. Anderson in 1823, made out to send with the other papers to the House— Mr Meech was here relating to the appointment of a
Collector at Allburg in Vermont—he expressed an opinion that Mr Fiske the present Collector would not be able to clear up the charges against him, and renewed the application which he had heretofore made in behalf of a Dr Hyde, a relation of his— Mr Clay was out again the first time for several days and is much emaciated— He is still for postponing the answer to the Resolution of the House— I disapproved the decision of a Court Martial upon Captain and approved Sentences, Cashiering Captain Pentland and Gray— Mr Rush brought me recommendations for Collector at Georgetown, and at York town, Virginia— George Sullivan called; and is going shortly to leave the City— He pleaded again in behalf of the final success of E. Macon, and said little of his own keen correspondence with Govr. L. Lincoln of Masstts.

Dr Watkins called to recommend a friend of his for the appointment of Collector at Georgetown. He also spoke of the purchase by Major Eaton, the Senator from Tennessee of the Washington City Gazette; the name of which is now changed to that of the United States Telegraph. The rumour is that a fund of 30 000 dollars has been subscribed to maintain it as a professed opposition paper for the overthrow of the Administration. Watkins says that Thomas Law declares Jonathan Elliot publisher of the City Gazette told him he took for ready cash two thousand dollars less than were offered him if he would take General Jackson’s Notes in payment. This I do not believe. Watkins says also that Mr Calhoun is charged with having miscounted in declaring a vote in the Senate— Mr Kilgour came to apply for the appointment of Collector at St. Mary’s in Maryland where there is likely to be a vacancy— Mr George Hay was here to decline dining with me next Friday— He will not associate abroad while his character is under discussion in the Senate— John Findlay came with a Mr Norris who applies for admission for his Son, as a Cadet at West-Point; and brought me a Letter of recommendation of the Son from Mr Andrew Gregg— John Mitchell, member of the House from Pennsylvania came with them— William Good, for an appointment of Justice of the Peace at Georgetown— Dr Holcombe, brought Mr Newbold and Mr Wistar as visitors— Mr Rush called twice; with Letters from Edward Thomson, and orders for the Captains of Revenue Cutters which are to be stationed off the Coast to meet 5 of Thompsons Ships coming from India, and bring them into Philadelphia. Mr Southard introduced here three young men from New-Jersey as visitors whose names I lost, and whose curiosity was the cause of their visit— Mr Southard was taken seriously ill this Evening. Mr Albert Gallatin called also on a visit from Baltimore where he has taken with his family his winter Residence— He attributes to Mrs Gallatin his determination not to go to Panama— Owen of Alabama introduced Mr Armstrong the Marshal of that District and Mr Pearce, Elisha Potter and Professor Parsons of Rhode-Island— Visits from Mr John Knapp of Boston, General Brown, Mr Evans of Michigan, and Mr M’Lean the Postmaster-General. The Politics of New-York still very much occupy General
General Brown, who is much interested in the course of the delegation of that State here— He speculates on the future with great earnestness— The Postmaster General proposes to appoint Mr Dupuy as Postmaster at New-Orleans, and Mr Parrott late a Senator from New-Hampshire as Postmaster at Portsmouth.

row.cell: Signed Land-grants within a few days

div.p: 15. VI. Central Market

Dr Wallace came to solicit the appointment of health-Officer at Alexandria, if an Act now before Congress for establishing a Lazaretto at that place should be passed— Mr Scott came to enquire of my determination upon the case of Genl. Bissell— I told him that the Senate not having acted upon the nomination I had sent in, I did not conceive myself authorised by Law to act— He said Bissell was then just where he had been before; which I much regretted but could not remedy— Vinton and M’Lean called for a visit— M’Kee to urge ardently the appointment of W. Crawford as District Judge in Alabama— Mr. M’Ilvaine the Senator from New-Jersey came and introduced his Son Joseph. He told me it was the first time he had been out for several weeks. He was taken very ill again this Evening. Genl. Brown came to introduce Genl. Atkinson, who comes from a Station Westward of the Missouri River— Coll. Roberdeau introduced Coll. Abert. Dr Holcombe came to pay a morning visit— He said he had yet hopes that Mr Gaillard would recover. Mr Powell renewed a recommendation in favour of a Mr Symmes for an appointment. Mr Rush read me perhaps his Report recommending the extension of the term limited upon drawbacks— Mr Bailey was here part of the Evening; and I received a Note from Mr Clay mentioning a Resolution passed this day in Session upon Executive business, with a view to embarrass me and which he thinks should be cautiously answered. Incedo per ignes.
16. V:30. Capitol.

Mr Lowrie brought me this morning the two Resolutions of the Senate adopted in Executive Session— The first declares that the question of the expediency of the Panama Mission, ought to be debated in Senate with open doors, unless the publication of the documents to which it would be necessary to refer in debate would prejudice existing Negotiations— The Second is a respectful request to the President of the United States, to inform the President whether such objection exists to the publication of all or of any part of those documents, and if so to specify to what part it applies?— These Resolutions are the fruit of the ingenuity of Martin van Buren, and bear the impress of his character— The Resolution to debate an Executive
nomination with open doors is without example; and the 36th. Rule of the Senate is explicit and unqualified, that all documents communicated in confidence by the President to the Senate shall be kept secret by the members— The request to me to specify the particular documents the publication of which would affect existing negotiations was delicate and ensnaring. The limitation was not of papers the publication of which might be injurious; but merely of such as would affect existing negotiations; and this being necessarily a matter of opinion if I should specify passages in the documents as of such a character, any Senator might make it a question for discussion in the Senate, and they might finally publish the whole under the colour of entertaining an opinion different from mine upon the probable effect of the publication— Besides, should the precedent once be established of opening the doors of the Senate, in the midst of a debate upon Executive business, there could be no prospect of ever keeping them shut again. I answered the Resolutions of the Senate, by a Message stating that all the communications I had made to the Senate on this Subject had been confidential, and that believing it important for the Public Interest that the Confidence between the Executive and the Senate should continue unimpaired, I should leave to themselves the determination of a question, upon the motives for which, not being informed of them, I was not competent to decide. W. H. Harrison called to speak about the case of Bissell, and is extremely anxious that he should be restored to the army with the rank that he had— This was an old controversy between Mr Monroe and the Senate, in consequence of which the Office of Colonel of the second Regiment of Artillery has remained four years vacant— The Office of Adjutant General had remained in the same condition— At the extra Session of the Senate last March I nominated Coll. Jones to be the Adjutant General, and the Senate advised and consented to the Appointment— On the nomination of Bissell now, they have taken a different course, by passing a Resolution, that in the opinion of the Senate Bissell is entitled to rank as Coll. in the army from 1812. and as Brigadier General by Brevet from 1814 and that the President may arrange him accordingly— Which Resolution assumes that the President is to act according to the Senate’s opinion of the Law, and that the Senate are to inform him how he may perform his duty— Harrison spoke also of their Resolutions of yesterday and apologized for having voted for them— Mr Seymour came to speak of the appointment of a Collector in Vermont— The Delegation have not yet determined whether to recommend the reappointment of Fisk or not— He spoke also of the Resolutions adopted yesterday by the Senate, which he disapproves.
